p: Different pathogenic blood-borne bacteria are regularly detected in mosquitoes [ 58, 59]. It is not yet clear whether the presence of these bacteria in mosquitoes may be explained by occasional ingestion with blood meals or acquisition from the environment, or whether these bacteria may multiply and eventually be transmitted during blood meals. Different pathogenic alpha-proteobacteria, including Anaplasma spp., Ehrlichia spp., Candidatus Neoehrlichia, Bartonella spp., and Rickettsia spp., have been identified (xeno-monitoring studies) in adult mosquitoes [ 59, 60]. More interestingly, the agent of febrile rickettsiosis, Rickettsia felis, has not only been identified in mosquitoes [ 58, 61] but also shown to be potentially transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes in laboratory experiments [ 62]. Francisella tularensis [ 63] is also carried by mosquitoes ( Aedes), which act as a main vector in Sweden and Finland, making it the first reported mosquito-borne bacterium [ 63].
